The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of theprevious week.Operations of Bomber Command had been restricted by weather, but two heavy attacks had been made on the previousSaturday and Sunday on Hamburg and Essen! 4,445 tons of bombs had been dropped. Leghorn had also been attacked by Lancastersreturning to this country from North Africa. Coastal command had sunk 2 U-boats. Enemy losses had been 14 destroyed,6 probably destroyed and 10 damaged. Our losses had been38 bombers, 15 fighters and 3 Coastal Command aircraft.United States Air Forces had bombed the submarine base , atTrOndheim. and the aluminium works at Heroya with successful results.- They had also made four attacks on Germany.Enemy air losses in the Mediterranean had been 180 destroyed(including 25 on the ground), 15 probably destroyed and 38 damagedOur losses had been 61 aircraft.United States Air Forces claimed to have hit 21 large Japaneseships and 5 destroyers.Shipping losses by enemy action during the previous week,including belated reports, and ships lost in the Sicilian operationsamounted to 63,000 tons.The War Cabinet were informed of the progress of operations in Sicily, where the Eighth Army had had the heaviest fighting.Some 75,000 prisoners had been taken, the bulk of which had beenItalians.. The news from Russia continued to be satisfactory. TheRussians had succeeded in restoring the whole of the ground theyhad lost in the Kursk salient and were now on the offensive to thenorth, east and south of Orel.The War Cabinet-Took note of these statements. national Day of 2. (43)282).THE MINISTER OP LABOUR AND NATIONAL SERVICE,referring to a statement on page 1 of W.P.(43)282, saidthat too much weight should not be attached to the argu-ment that Civil Servants, being in permanent andpensionable employment, were in a special position.Municipal employees were also in permanent pensionablepositions, but in law they were free to affiliate if they wanted to do so. He thought that the present difficulty had arisen largely from the way in which this matter hadbeen handled in 1939, when an answer had been given byMr. Chamberlain which had caused a good deal of resentmentAs a result of the discussions which had taken placesinee the present Government had been formed, the points at issue in regard to the Trade. Disputes and TradesUnion Act as a whole had now been narrowed down to thisrelatively small issue of affiliation. The impression in Trade Union circles was that the Government as a whole were not indisposed to make a change, but that the ToryParty was putting obstacles in the way.On the other hand, it was urged that this was a very controversial matter which had been raised by the Labour iParty, and an already difficult position had been made faxmore acute by the action taken by the Union of Post QBEDi"Workers in passing a resolution at their Annual Conferencapplying for affiliation to the T.U.C, It was also pointed out that legislation on this subject would be
difficult to reconcile with the undertaking that contro-versial legislation should be avoidsdoThe War Cabinet were informed that the PrimeMinister had undertaken to receive a Deputation from three Civil Service Unions, namely, the Post office engineering Union, the Inland Revenue Staff Federation,and the Civil Service Clerical Association.THE PRIME MINISTER said that he would, of course,infox^m his colleagues of the line which he proposed totake, before seeing the Deputation.THE MINISTER OF LABOUR AND NATIONAL SERVICEsuggested that the best course might be that the PrimeMinister should inform the Deputation that the Govern-raent were not opposed to this matter being reopened andre-discussed provided that the threat to flout the lawwas first withdrawn.THE PRIME MINISTER said that, on merits, he had not changed his views from those which he held when the Acthad been passed in 1927* If any amendment of Act wasto be put forward, his support of it would be on theground that such action would go a long way to removea erase of resentment and would encourage harmonious co-operation of the Trade Unions in the war effort.No decision was reached, and the WarCabinet agreed to resume the discussion at an early date.:y.'.y^y^V::'''^0yiOff ices of the War Cafe28TH '
